description.plain:
Brandon Paak Anderson, a.k.a. Anderson .Paak, is a singer, songwriter, producer, and drummer from Oxnard, California. He released his debut EP, Violets Are Blue, under his original moniker, Breezy Lovejoy, in 2010. He eventually began using his new stage name and released  O.B.E. Vol. 1 in June 2012 and Lovejoy in October 2012.

Before his 2014 album Venice, .Paak officially changed his name to Anderson .Paak. When asked if his name change was symbolic of a turning point in his career by Consequence of Sound, he stated:

Yeah, that was the case. […] and I felt like it was time to transition to a different name.

With his name change, .Paak was reborn. Venice, released a full two years after his last project showcased .Paak’s incredible versatility. “Milk n' Honey” showed .Paak’s storytelling ability. In “The City,” .Paak shows he can create a West Coast anthem. “Drugs,” the single that got .Paak noticed by Dre, is perhaps .Paak’s most telling song of his sound, with powerful vocals and progressive production on full display.

2015 was a standout year for .Paak, thanks to his guest features. Appearing on six songs from Dr. Dre’s Compton project, as well as two songs on The Game’s The Documentary 2.5, his popularity began to skyrocket. In late 2015, .Paak released two EP’s: The Anderson .Paak EP in collaboration with The Blended Babies and Link Up & Suede as one half of NxWorries with producer Knxwledge.

Riding the success of 2015, 2016 saw .Paak collaborate with many big name artists. Anderson was featured on Macklemore’s “Dance Off”, Domo Genesis' “Dapper”, KAYTRANDA’s “Glowed Up,” Snakehips “Money On Me”, ScHoolboy Q’s “Blank Face”, and Mac Miller’s “Dang!”.

In January of 2016, .Paak released his second album, Malibu. The album, sixteen tracks in length, is .Paak’s strongest work to date, showing the growth he’s made since his Breezy Lovejoy days. The album was met with incredible praise, receiving an 85 on Metacritic, making it one of the most well-received albums of the year.

After the release of Malibu, .Paak announced that he signed to Dr. Dre’s Aftermath Entertainment. Paak was also a member of 2016’s XXL Freshman Issue.

He released his third studio album, Oxnard, on November 16, 2018. He would release two singles prior to the project: “Tints”, featuring Kendrick Lamar, and “Who R U?”, produced in part by Dr. Dre. The album was received well by critics, and debuted at #11 on the Billboard 200. The song “Bubblin” won “Best Rap Performance” at the 61st Grammy Awards on May 17, 2019.

On April 12, 2019, he released his fourth studio album, Ventura. The star-studded project features such artists as André 3000, Smokey Robinson, Lalah Hathaway, and more. Ventura would become Paak’s first US Top Ten hit, debuting at #4 on the Billboard 200.

songs.title: Come Down

description.plain:
“Come Down” is the fourth single from Anderson .Paak’s sophomore LP Malibu. The song was produced by Hi-Tek, and is notable for its groovy bass line and chant vocals. The official remix features a guest verse from T.I.

The song was featured in a Nike commercial for Kevin Durant’s new signature shoe, the Zoom KD9. As well as the Madden 17 main-menu tracklist.

Producer Hi-Tek talked about how the song came together:


That beat—well, the bassline—I recorded that idea during the second Reflection Eternal album. I kept going back to it every so often, but I could never find the right drum pattern for it. One day, in 2015, I finally figured it out. I was chopping these drums up and it just clicked in my head, so I went back to that bassline. It was maybe 100 BPMs at the time, so I slowed it down—the Anderson .Paak joint is 98 BPMs, so I didn’t have to slow it down too much—but I slowed it down and added it to the drum track.

Anderson had DM’d me on Twitter and said, ‘Wassup, I’m trying to get some stuff from you. I’m wrapping my album up. I wanna see what you got.’ So I asked him what he was looking for and he said, ‘I want a ‘Devil’s Pie’-type joint.’ I was like, ‘Yo, God works in mysterious ways. I got it already!’ I had just worked on the track like three weeks before he hit me up.

I sent him the track. He hit me right back asking for a couple more. Usually, when artists do that, it means they don’t like what you sent them [laughs]. A month later, he hit me out of the blue and was like, ‘I’m working on your joint tonight.’ Then he hit me back a few days later and sent me the finished vocals, and I was like, ‘Wow, this shit’s outta here!’ I asked him, ‘Anything else you hearing on the track?’ He was like, ‘Think you can add some guitar?’ That’s where you hear more of the rock-type guitar when his verse starts, that was his idea. I had my man Cameron Brown—great guitarist, a young cat from Cincinnati—he played those guitar parts.

The way he attacked it reminds me of, like, James Brown. I salute Anderson, man. He gave me a chance to reinvent that Hi-Tek sound. That’s what people like from me.

songs.title: Bubblin

description.plain:
First debuted live at Splash! 19 music festival in Germany, “Bubblin” is the second single released by Anderson .Paak in 2018. It was preceded by “‘Til It’s Over,” which featured in an ad for the Apple Homepod.

A music video for “Bubblin” was released later the same day, directed by Calmatic. Paak’s oldest son, Soul, appears in the video, as do the members of Paak’s band, The Free Nationals.

The single premiered on Zane Lowe’s Beats 1 Radio show as a World Record:

https://twitter.com/AndersonPaak/status/997156953460588545?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw









Of the song, Paak told Lowe:

“I had the beat from Jahlil Beats and AntMan Wonder. I was trying to get Little Simz to rap on it first because she was in the studio too. I remember trying to get other people on it, and then eventually I just wrote on it.

In a text message .Paak received from his mom, she told him her interpretation of the song:

Love “Bubblin” Brandon. Tell me if I’m close. The song’s subliminal message is about the love of money and how it makes people act to get it and how it changes people. The ATM represents the abundance of it and also the insatiable desire of it and the inevitable detriment of it. How did I do?

To which .Paak replied, “Yes spot on!!!”

songs.title: The Bird

description.plain:
Fresh off his appearances on Dr. Dre’s and GoldLink’s 2015 albums, Oxnard native Anderson .Paak croons over simplistic but beautiful production.

.Paak sings of hardships of his youth, including his mother’s gambling problem and father’s absence. Despite these struggles, Anderson promises he will continue on the path of righteousness until he reaches the top.

Luckily, with a predominant role on Dr. Dre’s Compton and two stellar features on The Game’s The Documentary 2/2.5, Anderson has broken through.

description.plain:
The first single released from Anderson’s 2016 , Malibu, a followup to Venice. “The Season | Carry Me” picks right off where Venice left off, carrying a laid back, but powerful, vibe. “The Season | Carry Me” premiered on Dr. Dre’s The Pharmacy, episode 9.

During Anderson .Paak’s national TV debut on The Late Show with Steven Colbert, he played “The Season | Carry Me” and “Silicon Valley.”

https://youtu.be/g7cLZRqqznU

songs.title: Tints

description.plain:
As the first official single from Oxnard, “Tints” marks the third collaboration between Anderson .Paak and Kendrick Lamar. They had previously linked up on “Deep Water” from Dr. Dre’s Compton album, and “Bloody Waters” from the Black Panther soundtrack. On October 4th, 2018, the song debuted via Zane Lowe’s “World Record” on Beats1.

This is Anderson’s third single of 2018, following “‘Til It’s Over” and “Bubblin.” The track was first teased on September 23rd, 2018, with a picture posted on Anderson .Paak’s Instagram account. A stylized version of the photo also appears directly above the title on the cover art.

https://www.instagram.com/p/BoEua0-H7Qs/?taken-by=anderson._paak

The artwork is reminiscent of a movie poster, with both Kendrick and Anderson depicted as mechanics. They are also wearing Nike Cortez sneakers, of which Kendrick has a signature model.

songs.title: Put Me Thru

description.plain:
“Put Me Thru” directly follows “The Season / Carry Me”, where the final words we hear are:

Psychologist: I see here they call you a masochist
Leroy the Masochist: I like pain
Psychologist: Can you be specific? What kind of pain do you like?
Leroy the Masochist: Any kind of pain

This leads into a BDSM style song (just like “Off the Ground” from Venice) where Anderson details his love for the pain in their sexual relationship.

The song deals with emotional pain as well, in  being the more committed to a hectic, run-around relationship.

Paak and the Free Nationals said at their NPR Tiny Desk Concert that the song is about Free Nationals guitarist, Jose Rios’s ex-girlfriend.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ferZnZ0_rSM

songs.title: Silicon Valley

description.plain:
A smooth cut for the ladies emphasizing the importance of personal connection in an intimate relationship. Anderson presents the contradiction surrounding females with enhanced breasts (or as he affectionately refers to them: “tig-ol-bitties”), observing that while large breasts are certainly an attractive female body part to most guys, sometimes men are looking for more than just what’s on the surface.

https://twitter.com/AndersonPaak/status/684703734656450561

The title, “Silicon Valley”, is also some seriously clever wordplay on Anderson’s part. The girl’s tumultous breasts make up the hills of the valley he’s so desperate to get into – her heart.

The track is produced by Dem Jointz. This collaboration makes perfect sense, since they both had breakout guest appearances the previous year (2015) on Dr. Dre’s highly anticipated 3rd album Compton: A Soundtrack.

songs.title_with_featured: The Waters (Ft. BJ the Chicago Kid)

description.plain:
“The Waters” details the struggles of fame and making it big. While they may be celebrities now, BJ and Andy use water as a metaphor to help show us it can be tough to make it into the inner-circle of fame.

“The Waters” also serves as a slight interlude to the story of Malibu; the basis of the song doesn’t revolve around Andy’s girl, thus giving it a different theme and sound than the album.

The song was actually teased in .Paak’s mini-doc series A N I M A L, with some footage of the making of the song.

https://youtu.be/jQNVK0oUbQA

“The Waters” also serves as a slight interlude to the story of Malibu; the basis of the song doesn’t revolve around Andy’s girl, thus giving it a different theme and sound than the album.

The song was actually teased in .Paak’s mini-doc series A N I M A L, with some footage of the making of the song.

https://youtu.be/jQNVK0oUbQA

songs.title: Come Home

description.plain:
“Come Home” is a soulful throwback to the golden age of rhythmic soul, with a parodying “I-want-you-back” theme characteristic of songs from Motown Record’s golden age. The song’s style is complemented by rapper André 3000’s tongue-twisting featured verse.

The song essentially revolves around a man pleading for the return of his former partner. Over the course of the song, the speaker goes from wanting her back to seeking peace and establishing friendship.

songs.title: Make It Better

description.plain:
“Make It Better” is the second single released by Anderson .Paak for the album Ventura. Released through an episode of Anderson’s Beats 1 Show .Paak House Radio and a video on April 4, 2019, the song follows lovers that have fallen out of love.

The speaker, however, seeks a way to mend the relationship, hoping the partner also wants to reignite what was lost.

songs.title_with_featured: The Dreamer (Ft. Talib Kweli & Timan Family Choir)

description.plain:
With the backing of the  Timan Family Choir and the legendary Talib Kweli (½ of BlackStar) – .Paak delivers a truthful song about his struggles when he was younger and how he made it as an artist now.

Encouraging the next man with a dream and striving for success. Serves as a great emotional booster to the kids listening and a great way t o close off the album.

description.plain:
“Room In Here” is #10 on the album Malibu, and was released as a single on the heels of Paak’s collab project with Knxwledge.

On this song Paak and The Game talk about their pursuit of fine women, but rather than follow standard hip-hop tropes of “smash and pass,” they talk about deeper, more spiritual connections. The track features a jazzy piano loop with some classic boom bap drums.

songs.title: Lockdown

description.plain:
“Lockdown” is a protest song by Anderson .Paak, released on Juneteenth, a holiday celebrating the liberation of slaves on June 19, 1865. He details his experience at the Black Lives Matter protests held in Los Angeles in June 2020, as depicted on both the track’s front and back cover.

Anderson initially announced the single on June 18, 2020, revealing the title, cover art, and release date via Instagram and Twitter.

The music video features cameos from Jay Rock, Syd, SiR, Dominic Fike, Andra Day, and Jonathan “Dumbfoundead” Park.

songs.title: 6 Summers

description.plain:
As Anderson .Paak’s definitive political anthem, “6 Summers” covers many controversial aspects of American culture. He discusses consumerism, President Donald Trump’s sex scandal, and gun violence. Despite the heated, political tension that .Paak evokes throughout the song, he ultimately offers a strong personal message of love.

Anderson has expressed a desire to use his voice to tackle social issues in the country. In an interview with NPR, he said:

Every day there’s a new situation that’s going on. So I had to write about it. Some artists are not affected, socially, with what’s going on around them. They create their own thing, and then maybe that helps other people escape that. I do that, too. But I feel like with this album, I wanted to challenge myself and do other things.

body.plain:
As Anderson .Paak’s definitive political anthem, “6 Summers” covers many controversial aspects of American culture. He discusses consumerism, President Donald Trump’s sex scandal, and gun violence. Despite the heated, political tension that .Paak evokes throughout the song, he ultimately offers a strong personal message of love.

Anderson has expressed a desire to use his voice to tackle social issues in the country. In an interview with NPR, he said:

Every day there’s a new situation that’s going on. So I had to write about it. Some artists are not affected, socially, with what’s going on around them. They create their own thing, and then maybe that helps other people escape that. I do that, too. But I feel like with this album, I wanted to challenge myself and do other things.

songs.title: Parking Lot

description.plain:
“Parking Lot” is the eighth track from Anderson .Paak’s second studio album Malibu. The song is produced by .Paak himself along with Jose Rios who lends guitar to the track.

Cruising along at about 97 BPM, “Parking Lot” doesn’t follow a particular lyrical train of thought. It’s instead driven by a kick-and-clap drum beat and its catchy “1, 2, 3, come on, you feel me” hook. Without many synthesized instruments in the mix, its surf music-meets-R&B hybrid establishes a comfortable atmosphere not unlike summertime under the AC vent.

Vinson Cunningham of The New Yorker writes of the song:

Behind this blurriness lies what I love about “Parking Lot,” and why it suits the hot months so well. (As does, by the way, the rest of “Malibu.” In retrospect, its January release date was a bit of a shame.) Summer, for me, so often becomes a kind of summary—it’s the season I most easily, and most happily, forget. When I try to remember what it was, exactly, that I loved about a particular July, what arrives is a series of surprisingly vivid impressions, distorted by time—or, as .Paak says, by a “combination of all my life’s complaints and a few strong drinks.”

The song, which is a standout track from the critically acclaimed Malibu album, captures a mood of celebration, summer days, and youthful swagger.

songs.title: Celebrate

description.plain:
“Celebrate” finds Anderson mulling over the positives others take for granted, such as seeing one’s children grow to be adult, looking out over the West LA skyline and even simply being alive.

It’s a sobering reminder that it’s easy to take things for granted, and we should actively appreciate the seeming inconsequential – even menial positives call for a celebration!

songs.title: Might Be

The fourth song off of Anderson’s album ‘Venice’ – his first album made since changing his name from Breezy Lovejoy.

He samples a 1995 cover of the song ‘Who Can I Run To’, by female American R&B quartet “Xscape”.

“Might Be” was further flipped by rapper “DJ LUKE NASTYY” in his “Might Be Freestyle”.

songs.title: ’Til It’s Over

description.plain:
.Paak returns with his first lead role since his collab with Knxwledge for Yes Lawd!. He brings his classic effortless swag and wordplay to the genre-defying track courtesy of Jeff Kleinman and Michael Uzowuru; perhaps a preview for his forthcoming album which we “can definitely expect this year, sometime,” he told Triple J.

The track premiered during a Spike Jonze-directed commercial for the Apple Homepod on March 5, 2018.

songs.title: Cheers

description.plain: “Cheers” features a verse from former A Tribe Called Quest member Q-Tip. On the song, both .Paak, and Tip reminisce about lost friends. These include .Paak’s friend and collaborator Mac Miller, and Q-Tip’s childhood-friend and former A Tribe Called Quest member Phife Dawg. Despite the heavy subject matter, the song is not sad, as they are giving love to their friends, and celebrating them with a toast; hence the name “Cheers.”

songs.title: Your Prime

description.plain:
Throughout Malibu, Anderson .Paak has taken us on quite the ride with the girl. We find out her heart doesn’t stand a chance, that she’s abusive, but Andy likes it, she isn’t a dancer and Anderson is really good in bed. In “Your Prime,” we find out this girl is actually quite young; she’s still in college. Since Anderson turned 30 in 2016, the age gap is anywhere between eight to twelve years.

This song follows a similar theme to Tyler, The Creators 2015 hit “FUCKING YOUNG / PERFECT.”

songs.title: Winners Circle

description.plain:
On “Winners Circle” .Paak details an experience with a woman that contrasts all the other relationships he’s been in throughout his life.

Since being famous, he has developed a formulaic method of getting the woman he dates into bed and, on this track, his partner makes him work for it. Other women usually throw themselves at him so this unusual behavior gives him a new appreciation and respect for what he believes is a rare type of woman.

songs.title: Milk n’ Honey

description.plain:
“Milk and Honey” is from Exodus 3:8:

So I have come down to rescue them from the hand of the Egyptians and to bring them up out of that land into a good and spacious land, a land flowing with milk and honey–the home of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites.

Anderson uses ‘Milk and Honey’ to describe his life at the time. Using fantastic storytelling form, .Paak tells a detailed story of how he gets tangled up with the wrong girl.

This is the second track off of Anderson .Paak’s debut studio album, but only the first song as it follows the intro.

songs.title: Brother’s Keeper

description.plain:
“Brother’s Keeper” features Pusha-T and .Paak trading bars over what it means to be “your brother’s keeper”.

The song’s title is a reference to a CNN interview of the same name, which details Pusha-T and No Malice’s journey from selling drugs to becoming the famed rap duo Clipse.

songs.title: King James

description.plain:
“King James” is the seventh track and first single to Anderson .Paak’s fourth album Ventura.

The track acts as an ode to businessman, philanthropist, and basketball player Lebron James and how he pushes forward with his high status despite the challenges set around him. By persevering from this high status, he has the potential to uplift members of his community. Anderson seeks to praise this effort and bring more members of his community along in the face of a history of injustice.

songs.title_with_featured: Anywhere (Ft. The Last Artful, Dodgr & Snoop Dogg)

description.plain:
“Anywhere” marks .Paak’s first collaboration with West Coast legend Snoop Dogg and Portland rapper The Last Artful, Dodgr.

Produced by J.LBS, the song features an instrumental reminiscent of classic era G-funk, as each artist fondly engages in 90’s romanticism. This is typified in the hook, through a sample of funk group One Way’s 1982 track “Cutie Pie”. Moreover, .Paak and Dodgr further indulge in 80’s and 90’s R&B nostalgia, whilst Snoop pays homage to West Coast legends Warren G and Nate Dogg.

songs.full_title: CUT EM IN by Anderson .Paak (Ft. Rick Ross)
songs.title: CUT EM IN

description.plain:
“CUT EM IN” is Anderson .Paak’s second release of 2020, following his BLM protest track “Lockdown.” The track sees him and collaborator Rick Ross rapping about their finances, explaining how they’ll reward good friends by ‘cutting them in’ to a slice of their profits. They also talk about how sometimes people need enemies in their lives, people that don’t want them to prosper – this hate is what drives them to reach greater heights.
Notably, the song takes more of a hip-hop feel than .Paak’s previous singing-focused songs, with the pair spitting over a catchy electric guitar/piano beat produced by Hit-Boy, Corbett and G. Ry.

songs.title: Miss Right

description.plain:
Fifth track on Venice. This is a slow and melodic song about finding the right girl, one who fits all of his desires and needs.

In an interview on Sway In The Morning, he related this song with “Drugs”, another song on the album, saying:

[This song is about] miss right. The right one. After you do the drugs and you fall in love, like after the drugs are wearing off. After we come out of that cave, out [of] the darkness.

https://youtu.be/gasKY7t30io?t=9m22s

songs.title: Who R U?

description.plain:
Released on November 9, 2018, “Who R U?” is the second single from Oxnard. The track features backing vocals from legendary producer Dr. Dre, who also co-produced and mixed the track.

The song artwork seems to continue the movie theme that is prominent on the artwork for the track “Tints.” On the artwork for this song, Anderson is wearing a suit, and is looking in a mirror that is reminiscent of one seen in a dressing room. This could signify that he is feeling like a movie star, and he wants to look the part.

description.plain:
“Sweet Chick” is the thirteenth track on Oxnard. On the song, Anderson and BJ talk about all the different women that have been in their lives, especially now that they’re famous and on tour. These range from, a “sweet bitch,” to a cougar, to a “yogi bitch.”

BJ the Chicago Kid and Anderson .Paak have previously collaborated on the track “The Waters” from .Paak’s second album, Malibu.

description.plain: Saviers Road is a main street in Anderson’s hometown Oxnard, CA. The song title is a double entendre and flips the name of the street. The song really should be spelled “saviors” road, but it’s not about the street, but about being “saved” by God and now being famous.

songs.title: Water Fall (Interluuube)

description.plain: The two-minute interlude “Water Fall” is a sexy ballad included on the second half of Anderson .Paak’s Grammy-nominated Malibu album. The music backing “Water Fall” seems inspired by soundtrack of a 70’s blaxploitation film. The jazzy churning chords intermix with Isley Brothers-like electric guitar flourishes as Anderson sings his way through the climax and aftermath of a female orgasm.

songs.title: Headlow

description.plain:
On “Headlow” Anderson .Paak sings about a time when he received oral sex on the I-9 freeway. Throughout the song, Anderson repeats “just keep your head low,” which is a play on the phrase “keep your head high.”

The track features singer Norelle (R&B), which marks the first collaboration between the two artists. The song is immediately followed-up by “Tints” which seems to be connected, since having tinted windows would help keep his vehicle low-key.

songs.title: JEWELZ

description.plain:
The upbeat, pitched-up “JEWELZ” is Anderson .Paak’s first collaboration with acclaimed producer Timbaland, first teased in a brief video featuring the duo working on the track. The track finally released on October 6, 2020.

During the COVID-19 quarantine in April, Anderson danced to the song with his son on Instagram Live, which has now been reuploaded to YouTube on his son’s channel.

However, in light of George Floyd’s murder in May, which triggered nationwide protests against police brutality, Anderson shelved JEWELZ and instead released Lockdown, which addressed the moment.

But fans still demanded the song’s release, highlighted in a teaser for the song’s actual release. Another teaser, featuring an animation of the dance performed by Anderson and his son, was released on his Instagram, teasing a music video for the song.

songs.full_title: Mansa Musa by Anderson .Paak (Ft. Cocoa Sarai & Dr. Dre)
songs.title: Mansa Musa
songs.title_with_featured: Mansa Musa (Ft. Cocoa Sarai & Dr. Dre)

description.plain:
Mansa Musa was the tenth sultan of the ancient empire of Mali. Mansa Musa is known as the richest person in history. On his way to participate in the Hajj, he is credited with giving so much gold away to communities on his path that the subsequent inflation crashed their economies and had repercussions all over the Islamic Empires and Maghreb. During his reign his empire may have been the largest producer of gold in the world.

Through comparing himself to Mansa Musa, .Paak invokes power and wealth, concepts that he entrenches further with a feature from Dr. Dre, an undeniably dominant force in hip-hop.

songs.full_title: The Chase by Anderson .Paak (Ft. Kadhja Bonet)
songs.title: The Chase

description.plain:
“The Chase” marks the first collaboration between .Paak and Kadhja Bonet, who also is featured on  “6 Summers,” “Trippy,” “Brother’s Keeper,” and “Headlow” off of Oxnard.

The track is marked by the sound of a flute flying around, before the drums, ‘70s-violins and a guitar setting the pace on something that sounds taken from ’ Shaft'-soundtrack. Retro, funky and with plenty of punch.

This song is about pursuing fame and glory or a way to get out of a situation. A lot of the messages in the song relate to driving and the road. The outro is an encouragement to the listeners to “chase” their dreams.
